title: Bank of Cyprus sells Russian unit to draw line under global ambitions
text:

Fri, Jul 17, 2015, 15:01 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 29 mins Bank of Cyprus sells Russian unit to draw line under global ambitions By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 11 minutes ago +0.003 
The bailed-out bank is restructuring to focus on its home markets, instead of overseas ventures 
Bank of Cyprus (Frankfurt: BC9N.F - news ) has sold its Russian subsidiary to banking tycoon Artyom Avetisyan in a bid to cut its losses in the country and draw a line under its pre-crash international ambitions. 
The bank had considered keeping the business, but decided in late 2014 that the worsening position of the sanction-hit Russian economy meant it was better to sell the loss-making unit. 
The €7m sale leaves the Bank of Cyprus with a loss of €5m, but also clears €700m of risk-weighted assets from its books, giving the group a substantial boost to its capital buffers. 
It is part of a series of foreign sales by the bank, which has slashed its balance sheet by 19pc since it was bailed out in March 2013 . 
It had already been writing down some of the losses on the Russian unit over the last six months in preparation for the sale. 
The group will still keep representative offices in Moscow and St Petersburg. 
“In light of the deteriorating economic conditions in Russia since mid-December 2014, the Bank proceeded to reassess its operations in that country and significantly increased the level of provisions for impairment of its loans and other assets, reflecting a deliberately more conservative stance regarding the Russian economic outlook and significantly reducing the Group’s exposure to Russia,” Bank of Cyprus said. 
“Specifically, the Bank recorded €289m of provisions for impairment during the fourth quarter of 2014 and the first quarter of 2015 in relation to its Russian operations.” 
Bank of Cyprus crashed in 2013 and had to be bailed out (Credit: REUTERS/Yannis Behrakis) 
The sale covers assets including an 80pc stake in Uniastrum Bank and 80pc of Uniastrum Leasing as well as a portfolio of other loans in the country. 
As a result Bank of Cyprus now has a remaining portfolio of €117m of assets in Russia, which it expects to run down in the coming years. 
Bank of Cyprus has already sold its Ukrainian subsidiary, and its only remaining overseas unit is its UK arm . It intends to keep the unit, which has 40,000 customers and has offices in London and Birmingham. 
The bank is listed on the stock markets in Cyprus and Athens, and is looking to move its secondary listing from Athens and to a more liquid market. Given its British operations, a London listing is one option. 
Former Royal Bank of Scotland executive John Hourican has been Bank of Cyprus’ chief executive for the two years since it was bailed out, and hopes to return it to profit by exiting the struggling parts of the business. 
It recorded an underlying profit of €31m in 2014, before restructuring costs and the losses incurred on asset sales. That compared with a €359m loss in 2013. 
However, Mr Hourican is set to leave the role later this summer.
